A Unified Analysis of Federated Learning with Arbitrary Client Participation

Shiqiang Wang
IBM T. J. Watson Research Center
Yorktown Heights, NY 10598
wangshiq@us.ibm.com
&Mingyue Ji
Department of ECE, University of Utah
Salt Lake City, UT 84112
mingyue.ji@utah.edu
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) faces challenges of intermittent client availability and computation/communication efficiency. As a result, only a small subset of clients can participate in FL at a given time. It is important to understand how partial client participation affects convergence, but most existing works have either considered idealized participation patterns or obtained results with non-zero optimality error for generic patterns. In this paper, we provide a unified convergence analysis for FL with arbitrary client participation. We first introduce a generalized version of federated averaging (FedAvg) that amplifies parameter updates at an interval of multiple FL rounds. Then, we present a novel analysis that captures the effect of client participation in a single term. By analyzing this term, we obtain convergence upper bounds for a wide range of participation patterns, including both non-stochastic and stochastic cases, which match either the lower bound of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) or the state-of-the-art results in specific settings. We also discuss various insights, recommendations, and experimental results.

1 Introduction

We consider a federated learning (FL) problem with Nğ‘N clients [17, 20, 38]. Our goal is to minimize:

fâ€‹(ğ±):=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1NFnâ€‹(ğ±),assignğ‘“ğ±1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±\displaystyle\textstyle f(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}F_{n}(\mathbf{x}), (1)

where ğ±âˆˆâ„mğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} is an mğ‘šm-dimensional model parameter. The local objective Fnâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±F_{n}(\mathbf{x}) of each clientÂ nğ‘›n is usually defined as Fnâ€‹(ğ±):=ğ”¼Î¾nâˆ¼ğ’Ÿnâ€‹[â„“nâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾n)]assignsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘›subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›delimited-[]subscriptâ„“ğ‘›ğ±subscriptğœ‰ğ‘›F_{n}(\mathbf{x}):=\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{n}\sim\mathcal{D}_{n}}\left[\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi_{n})\right], where ğ’Ÿnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›\mathcal{D}_{n} is the distribution of client nğ‘›nâ€™s local data, which cannot be observed globally because the data remains private, and â„“nâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)subscriptâ„“ğ‘›ğ±ğœ‰\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi) is the per-sample loss function for parameter ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} and input data Î¾ğœ‰\xi. The objective (1) can be extended to a weighted average, but we do not write out the weights and consider them as part of â„“nâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)subscriptâ„“ğ‘›ğ±ğœ‰\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi) and Fnâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±F_{n}(\mathbf{x}). A canonical way of solving (1) is to use federated averaging (FedAvg) [24], which is a form of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) that operates in multiple rounds, where each round includes multiple local update steps followed by communication between clients and a server to synchronize the updates.

Partial Participation. A major challenge in FL is that clients only intermittently participate in the collaborative training process [3]. The reason is twofold. First, FL applications usually have a large pool of clients. It is impractical to have all clients participating in all FL rounds, because it would require computation and communication that can consume a large amount of energy and also lead to network congestion. Second, clients may become unavailable from time to time. For example, if the client devices are smartphones, they may be willing to participate in FL only when they are charging (usually at night), to avoid draining the battery in outdoor environments where no charger is available.

Open Problem. The convergence of FL algorithms with realistic client participation patterns has not been fully understood. Most existing works on partial participation have only considered idealized scenarios, such as those where clients are randomly selected according to a given probability distribution that is independent across roundsÂ [4, 8, 9, 18, 21, 22, 36]. They cannot incorporate cases where clients are unavailable for a period of time. Some recent results considering general scenarios either include a constant error term that does not vanish at convergence [37, 5] or are otherwise less competitive than state-of-the-art results obtained in idealized settings [12, 35]. Therefore, we ask:
1. What classes of participation patterns have guaranteed convergence to zero error?
2. For these classes, can the convergence rate match with that obtained in idealized scenarios?

To answer these questions, we need to overcome two challenges. First, we need to devise a unified analytical methodology for obtaining the convergence rates under various participation patterns. Second, we need a general and realistic algorithm for cross-device FL, with appropriate control options that can be configured to make the convergence rate competitive.

Our Contributions. In this paper, we overcome these challenges and give answers to the two questions above. We first introduce a generalized version of FedAvg, which amplifies the parameter updates after every Pğ‘ƒP rounds, for some Pâ‰¥1ğ‘ƒ1P\geq 1. When P=1ğ‘ƒ1P=1, our setting is the same as FedAvg with two-sided learning rates [18, 36], but we focus on an extended setup where Pğ‘ƒP can be greater than one. For this generalized FedAvg algorithm, we perform a new convergence analysis that unifies the effect of partial participation into a single term (Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in SectionÂ 3). This allows us to decouple our main convergence analysis from the analysis on partial participation, which largely simplifies the analytical procedure. Our novel methodology gives the results shown in TableÂ 1, for a broad range of participation patterns. These patterns include non-stochastic and regularized participation, where all clients participate equally but not simultaneously within Pğ‘ƒP rounds, and stochastic participation settings including ergodic, stationary and strongly mixing (e.g., Markov process), and independent. For the stochastic participation, we provide both expected and high probability convergence bounds, where the expected rates match the state-of-the-art FedAvg convergence rates that were derived for the idealized setting of random participation following an independent distribution. Furthermore, we provide new insights related to non-IID data, amplification of updates, â€œlinear speedupâ€ [39], etc.

To summarize, our main contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We introduce a generalized FedAvg algorithm which amplifies the updates aggregated over multiple rounds, where the amplification interval Pğ‘ƒP can be tuned for the best convergence.

  • â€¢

    We present novel analysis and unified methodology for obtaining competitive convergence upper bounds with arbitrary client participation patterns.

  • â€¢

    We discuss important insights from both the theoretical and experimental results.

Related Work. FedAvg [24] is characterized by partial client participation and multiple local updates in each round. In the case of full participation, FedAvg is also known as local SGD [10, 14, 23, 28, 29, 30] and parallel restarted SGD [40]. Partial participation was considered in [4, 8, 9, 18, 21, 22, 36], with the assumption that clients are selected to participate probabilistically according to a given distribution that is independent across rounds. Some recent works have started to incorporate unavailable clients. For example, the work in [27] allows inactive clients, but the theoretical result does not guarantee convergence if a client participates with zero probability in a certain round. Similarly, the result in [37, 5] includes a constant error term in the case of general participation in cross-device FL. Other works have obtained convergence rates related to the maximum number of inactive rounds, based on additional assumptions such as Hessian Lipschitz [12] and bounded gradient norm [35]. Their theory also requires all clients to participate once at the beginning (see [12, Remark 5.2]). In contrast, our result in this paper is based on a minimal set of assumptions. We consider a simple algorithm without requiring initial full participation, and we provide a better rate of convergence to zero error (see TableÂ 1). Moreover, existing methods usually have separate analyses and results for each specific class of participation pattern, whereas we present a unified framework that largely simplifies the analytical procedure. Some more discussions on related works are in AppendixÂ A.

2 Generalized FedAvg with Amplified Updates

We consider a generalized version of FedAvg as shown in AlgorithmÂ 1. In this algorithm, we define qtnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›q_{t}^{n} to be the participation weight of client nğ‘›n in round tğ‘¡t. If qtn=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›0q_{t}^{n}=0, the client does not participate in this round. Each client nğ‘›n participates whenever qtn>0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›0q_{t}^{n}>0, where the weight qtnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›q_{t}^{n} is applied in the global update step in LineÂ 1. For mathematical convenience in our analysis, we assume in AlgorithmÂ 1 that all clients compute their local updates in LinesÂ 1â€“1, regardless of whether they participate in the current round or not. We emphasize that this is logically equivalent to the practical setting where non-participating clients do not compute, because their computations have no effect in subsequent rounds when qtn=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›0q_{t}^{n}=0 (see LineÂ 1). In every round tğ‘¡t, each client nğ‘›n computes Iğ¼I steps of local updates according to LineÂ 1, where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is the local learning rate and ğ nâ€‹(ğ²t,in)subscriptğ ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}) is the stochastic gradient of Fnâ€‹(ğ²t,in)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›F_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}) such that ğ”¼â€‹[ğ nâ€‹(ğ²t,in)|ğ²t,in]=âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ²t,in)ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n})\right|\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}\right]=\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}).

Starting at round t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}, the global updates are accumulated in ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} for Pğ‘ƒP rounds (LineÂ 1). At the end of every interval of Pğ‘ƒP rounds, an amplification is applied to the accumulated updates (LineÂ 1). Since ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t} is first updated without amplification in rounds t0,â€¦,t0+Pâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¡0â€¦subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1t_{0},\ldots,t_{0}+P-1, LineÂ 1 adds ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} after multiplying Î·âˆ’1ğœ‚1\eta-1, which is equivalent to setting ğ±t+1subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1\mathbf{x}_{t+1} to ğ±t0+Î·â€‹ğ®subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘¡0ğœ‚ğ®\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}}+\eta\mathbf{u}. When Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1, there is no amplification and LineÂ 1 has no effect in this case. In general, we allow any Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 including values of Î·ğœ‚\eta that are less than one. When Î·<1ğœ‚1\eta<1, we reduce (instead of amplify) the updates. Intuitively, amplification with Î·>1ğœ‚1\eta>1 is usually preferred over reduction, because we can compute the gradients on similar model parameters in each round where only a small number of clients participates. After Pğ‘ƒP rounds, the accumulated updates provide a better estimation for the overall client population, and amplifying the updates allows the model parameter to progress towards the descent direction for the majority of clients (see AppendixÂ B.1 for an example). Also note that although Pğ‘ƒP is a parameter in our algorithm, the dominant terms of our convergence upper bounds shown in TableÂ 1 do not depend onÂ Pğ‘ƒP.

3 Convergence Analysis and Main Result

We analyze AlgorithmÂ 1 as follows. For ease of analysis, we assume that âˆ‘n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1 for qtnâ‰¥0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›0q_{t}^{n}\geq 0 for all tğ‘¡t.111When âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ‰ 1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\neq 1, the algorithm is equivalent to the case of {qtn}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\{q_{t}^{n}\} normalized to one and a global learning rate applied to the updates in each round. Since we already amplify the updates every Pğ‘ƒP rounds, we do not apply a separate global learning rate to each round. We also define ÏğœŒ\rho such that âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2â‰¤Ï2superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›2superscriptğœŒ2\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\leq\rho^{2} for all tğ‘¡t. As âˆ‘n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1, there always exists ÏğœŒ\rho such that Ï2â‰¤1superscriptğœŒ21\rho^{2}\leq 1. We define ğ’¬:={qtn:âˆ€n,t}assignğ’¬conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›for-allğ‘›ğ‘¡\mathcal{Q}:=\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall n,t\}. Mathematically, we use the conditional expectation ğ”¼[â‹…|ğ’¬]\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\cdot\right|\mathcal{Q}\right] to denote the case where ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} is given and the expectation is only over the stochastic gradient noise. In the case where ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} is stochastic, the full expectation ğ”¼â€‹[â‹…]ğ”¼delimited-[]â‹…\mathbb{E}\left[\cdot\right] is taken over both the noise and ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}. We make the following assumptions that are commonly used in the literature.

Assumption 1 (Lipschitz gradient).
â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ²)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ²â€–,âˆ€ğ±,ğ²,n.normâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ²ğ¿normğ±ğ²for-allğ±ğ²ğ‘›\displaystyle\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|\leq L\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\|,\forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},n. (2)
Assumption 2 (Unbiased stochastic gradient with bounded variance).
ğ”¼â€‹[ğ nâ€‹(ğ±)|ğ±]=âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)â€‹Â andğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ ğ‘›ğ±ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±Â and\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x})\right|\mathbf{x}\right]=\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})\textnormal{ and } ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ nâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2|ğ±]â‰¤Ïƒ2,âˆ€ğ±,n.ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±2ğ±superscriptğœ2for-allğ±ğ‘›\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathbf{x}\right]\leq\sigma^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},n. (3)
Assumption 3 (Bounded gradient divergence).
â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤d2,âˆ€ğ±,n.superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2superscriptğ‘‘2for-allğ±ğ‘›\displaystyle\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq d^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},n. (4)

The gradient divergence in AssumptionÂ 3 is related to the degree of non-IID data distribution across clients. To better interpret how different divergence components affect the convergence, we introduce an alternative set of divergence bounds in AssumptionÂ \NoHyper3â€™\endNoHyper as follows. We will show later (in SectionÂ 4) that if AssumptionÂ 3 holds, then AssumptionÂ \NoHyper3â€™\endNoHyper also holds with properly chosen Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2}, Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, and Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P).

Assumption \NoHyper3â€™\endNoHyper (Alternative gradient divergence bound).
â€–âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹[âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)]â€–2â‰¤Î²~2,âˆ€ğ±,t,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›delimited-[]âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2superscript~ğ›½2for-allğ±ğ‘¡\displaystyle\textstyle\left\|\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left[\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right]\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\beta}^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},t, (5)
âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤Î½~2,âˆ€ğ±,t,superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²âˆ‡subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ±2superscript~ğœˆ2for-allğ±ğ‘¡\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\nu}^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},t, (6)
â€–1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹(âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±))â€–2â‰¤Î´~2â€‹(P),âˆ€ğ±,t0.superscriptnorm1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒfor-allğ±subscriptğ‘¡0\displaystyle\textstyle\left\|\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left(\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right)\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P),\forall\mathbf{x},t_{0}. (7)

In the above, Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2} capture the gradient divergence in an arbitrary round tğ‘¡t, and Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) captures the divergence of time-averaged gradients over Pğ‘ƒP rounds, which is a function of Pğ‘ƒP. In particular, Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} is an upper bound of the divergence between the original objectiveâ€™s gradient âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±\nabla f(\mathbf{x}) and the averaged gradient among participating clients weighted by {qnt}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡\{q_{n}^{t}\}. When all the clients participate, we have qtn=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1ğ‘q_{t}^{n}=\frac{1}{N} and (5) holds with Î²~2=0superscript~ğ›½20\tilde{\beta}^{2}=0. The quantity Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2} is an upper bound of the divergence between each clientâ€™s gradient and the averaged gradient of participating clients, where the average is also weighted by {qnt}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡\{q_{n}^{t}\}. We will show in SectionÂ 4.1 that the overall divergence d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2} in AssumptionÂ 3 can be expressed as a sum of Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, as intuition suggests. The quantity Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in (7) extends Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} in (5) by computing the average over Pğ‘ƒP rounds (inside the norm) instead of a single round. When the weights {qnt}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡\{q_{n}^{t}\} are properly chosen, as Pğ‘ƒP gets large, the average qntsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¡q_{n}^{t} over Pğ‘ƒP rounds gets close to each other for different nğ‘›n, and Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) becomes small. We will formally analyze this behavior in SectionÂ 4.2.

In the following, let â„±:=fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâˆ—assignâ„±ğ‘“subscriptğ±0superscriptğ‘“\mathcal{F}:=f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{*}, where fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} is the true minimum of (1), i.e., fâˆ—:=minğ±â¡fâ€‹(ğ±)assignsuperscriptğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘“ğ±f^{*}:=\min_{\mathbf{x}}f(\mathbf{x}).

Theorem 3.1.

When AssumptionsÂ 1, 2, and \NoHyper3â€™\endNoHyper hold, Î³â‰¤112â€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pğ›¾112ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\leq\frac{1}{12LIP}, Î³â€‹Î·â‰¤1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pğ›¾ğœ‚1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\eta\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, and Pâ‰¤T2ğ‘ƒğ‘‡2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, we have

mintâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2|ğ’¬]subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’¬\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\min_{t}\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right]
â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(â„±Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹T+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+Î´~2â€‹(P)+(Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ï2+Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2)â€‹Ïƒ2).absentğ’ªâ„±ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscript~ğœˆ2superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğ‘ƒ2superscript~ğ›½2superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœŒ2ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{\mathcal{F}}{\gamma\eta IT}+\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)+\left(\gamma^{2}L^{2}I+\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\rho^{2}+\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\right)\sigma^{2}\Bigg{)}. (8)
Proof Sketch.

We first use smoothness to relate fâ€‹(ğ±t0+P)ğ‘“subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒf(\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}+P}) and fâ€‹(ğ±t0)ğ‘“subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘¡0f(\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}}), which includes an inner-product term that can be expanded into several terms. One of these terms includes âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ²t,in)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t0)âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ²ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘¡0\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t,i})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}}). We upper bound this term with three other terms including â€–ğ²t,inâˆ’âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹ğ²t,inâ€²â€–2superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğ²ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ²superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\left\|\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t,i}-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\mathbf{y}^{n^{\prime}}_{t,i}\right\|^{2}, â€–âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹ğ²t,inâ€²âˆ’ğ±t0â€–2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ²superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘¡02\left\|\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\mathbf{y}^{n^{\prime}}_{t,i}-\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}}\right\|^{2}, and Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P). The upper bounds of the first two terms are found by solving recurrence relations, where the recurrence for the second term includes the first term. This nested recurrence is a uniqueness in this proof. The full proof is given in AppendixÂ C. âˆ

For two specific (but different) learning rate configurations, we can obtain the following corollaries.

Corollary 3.2.

Choosing Î³=112â€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Tğ›¾112ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\gamma=\frac{1}{12LIP\sqrt{T}} and Î·=minâ¡{12â€‹Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹â„±Ïƒâ€‹Ï;12â€‹T}ğœ‚12ğ‘ƒğ¿ğ¼â„±ğœğœŒ12ğ‘‡\eta=\min\left\{\frac{12P\sqrt{LI\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho};12\sqrt{T}\right\}, for Pâ‰¤T2ğ‘ƒğ‘‡2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, we have

mintâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2|ğ’¬]â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹â„±Iâ€‹T+Lâ€‹Pâ€‹â„±T+Î½~2P2â€‹T+Î²~2T+Î´~2â€‹(P)+Ïƒ2Iâ€‹Pâ€‹T).subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’¬ğ’ªğœğœŒğ¿â„±ğ¼ğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘ƒâ„±ğ‘‡superscript~ğœˆ2superscriptğ‘ƒ2ğ‘‡superscript~ğ›½2ğ‘‡superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2ğ¼ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\displaystyle\min_{t}\,\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}\!+\!\frac{LP\mathcal{F}}{T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\nu}^{2}}{P^{2}T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\beta}^{2}}{T}\!+\!\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)\!+\!\frac{\sigma^{2}}{IPT}\Bigg{)}. (9)
Corollary 3.3.

If â„±Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tâ‰¤1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pâ„±ğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}}\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, choosing Î³=112â€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Tğ›¾112ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\gamma=\frac{1}{12LIP\sqrt{T}} and Î·=12â€‹Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹â„±Ïğœ‚12ğ‘ƒğ¿ğ¼â„±ğœŒ\eta=\frac{12P\sqrt{LI\mathcal{F}}}{\rho}, for Pâ‰¤T2ğ‘ƒğ‘‡2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, we have

mintâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2|ğ’¬]â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Ïƒ2)â€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹â„±Iâ€‹T+Î½~2P2â€‹T+Î²~2T+Î´~2â€‹(P)+Ïƒ2Iâ€‹Pâ€‹T).subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’¬ğ’ª1superscriptğœ2ğœŒğ¿â„±ğ¼ğ‘‡superscript~ğœˆ2superscriptğ‘ƒ2ğ‘‡superscript~ğ›½2ğ‘‡superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2ğ¼ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\displaystyle\min_{t}\,\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\!\frac{(1\!+\!\sigma^{2})\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\nu}^{2}}{P^{2}T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\beta}^{2}}{T}\!+\!\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)\!+\!\frac{\sigma^{2}}{IPT}\!\Bigg{)}.\! (10)

These two corollaries are key building blocks of our unified convergence analysis framework. The choice between them depends on whether and how fast Pğ‘ƒP grows with Tğ‘‡T. We will also see in the next section that Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is key in capturing the effect of different participation patterns. After deriving Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) such that (7) holds, plugging it back to one of the above corollaries gives the results in TableÂ 1.

4 Interpreting and Applying the Unified Framework

4.1 Discussion on Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2}: Decomposition of Divergence

In CorollariesÂ 3.2 and 3.3, we have an interesting observation that the term involving Î½~~ğœˆ\tilde{\nu} decreases with Pğ‘ƒP, whereas the term involving Î²~~ğ›½\tilde{\beta} does not decrease with Pğ‘ƒP. This suggests that when Pğ‘ƒP is large, the divergence term Î²~~ğ›½\tilde{\beta} has the main effect on convergence. We recall that Î½~~ğœˆ\tilde{\nu} captures the divergence between the gradient of each client and the average gradient of clients that participate in a round tğ‘¡t. Since the learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma is inversely proportional to both Iğ¼I and Pğ‘ƒP, a large Pğ‘ƒP gives a smaller learning rate which makes the divergence (related to Î½~~ğœˆ\tilde{\nu}) after Iğ¼I iterations in each round less significant. For the term with Î²~~ğ›½\tilde{\beta}, increasing Pğ‘ƒP does not have the same effect, because parameter averaging is only conducted across the participating clients instead of all the clients, and Î²~~ğ›½\tilde{\beta} captures the divergence with respect to all the clients. The effect of all clientsâ€™ participation pattern is captured by the term Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P).

From AssumptionÂ 3, by adding and subtracting âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²âˆ‡subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ±\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x}) inside the norm and expanding the square, we can obtain

âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}
=âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)â€–2+â€–âˆ‘nâ€²=1Nqtnâ€²â€‹âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤d2,absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²âˆ‡subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ±2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›â€²1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²âˆ‡subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2superscriptğ‘‘2\displaystyle\textstyle=\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}+\left\|\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq d^{2}, (11)

because âˆ‘n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1 and the inner-product term is zero. The two terms in the right-hand side (RHS) of (11) are equal to the left-hand side (LHS) of (5) and (6), respectively. We thus have the following result showing that Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2} can be seen as a decomposition of the original divergence d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2}.

Proposition 4.1.

There exist Î²~2superscript~ğ›½2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and Î½~2superscript~ğœˆ2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, such that Î²~2+Î½~2â‰¤d2superscript~ğ›½2superscript~ğœˆ2superscriptğ‘‘2\tilde{\beta}^{2}+\tilde{\nu}^{2}\leq d^{2} while satisfying (5) and (6).

4.2 Discussion on Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P): Effect of Partial Participation

The results in TheoremÂ 3.1 and CorollariesÂ 3.2 and 3.3 include a term of Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P). To guarantee convergence to zero error, Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) needs to be either equal to zero or decrease in Tğ‘‡T.

Condition for Î´~2â€‹(P)=0superscript~Î´2P0\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0. From (1), we know that 0=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1NFnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1N(Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±))01ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±ğ‘“ğ±1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±ğ‘“ğ±0=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-f(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-f(\mathbf{x})\right). Hence,

Î¼t0â€‹âˆ‘n=1N(Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±))=0subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±ğ‘“ğ±0\displaystyle\textstyle\mu_{t_{0}}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-f(\mathbf{x})\right)=0 (12)

for an arbitrary constant Î¼t0subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0\mu_{t_{0}}, which can possibly depend on t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}. Then, we obtain

â€–1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1âˆ‘n=1Nqtnâ€‹(âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±))â€–2=â€–âˆ‘n=1N1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtnâ€‹(âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±))â€–2superscriptnorm1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2\displaystyle\textstyle\left\|\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left(\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right)\right\|^{2}=\left\|\sum_{n=1}^{N}\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n}\left(\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right)\right\|^{2}
=â€–âˆ‘n=1N[1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtnâˆ’Î¼t0]â€‹(âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±))â€–2,absentsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘delimited-[]1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2\displaystyle\textstyle\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad=\left\|\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\!\left[\!\frac{1}{P}\!\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}\!q_{t}^{n}\!-\!\mu_{t_{0}}\!\right]\!\left(\nabla\!F_{n}(\mathbf{x})\!-\!\nabla\!f(\mathbf{x})\right)\right\|^{2}\!,\! (13)

where the last equality is due to (12). Since (13) is equal to the LHS of (7), we have the following.

Proposition 4.2 (Regularized participation).

If 1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtnâˆ’Î¼t0=01ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡00\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n}-\mu_{t_{0}}=0 for some Î¼t0subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0\mu_{t_{0}} and all nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, t0âˆˆ{0,P,2â€‹P,â€¦}subscriptğ‘¡00ğ‘ƒ2ğ‘ƒâ€¦t_{0}\in\{0,P,2P,\ldots\}, thenÂ (7) holds with Î´~2â€‹(P)=0superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ0\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0.

This implies that if Pğ‘ƒP is chosen so that the averaged participation weights over every interval of Pğ‘ƒP rounds (1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtn1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n}) are equal to each other among all the clients nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, i.e., regularized, then Î´~2â€‹(P)=0superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ0\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0. Together with CorollaryÂ 3.2 and PropositionÂ 4.1, we have the following.

Corollary 4.3 (Regularized participation).

If the condition of PropositionÂ 4.2 holds for Pâ‰¤T2ğ‘ƒğ‘‡2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, and we choose the learning rates according to CorollaryÂ 3.2, then

mintâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2|ğ’¬]subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’¬\displaystyle\min_{t}\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right] â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹â„±Iâ€‹T+Lâ€‹Pâ€‹â„±+d2+Ïƒ2T).absentğ’ªğœğœŒğ¿â„±ğ¼ğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘ƒâ„±superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptğœ2ğ‘‡\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}+\frac{LP\mathcal{F}+d^{2}+\sigma^{2}}{T}\Bigg{)}. (14)

If PropositionÂ 4.2 holds for a finite Pğ‘ƒP that does not depend on Tğ‘‡T, we obtain a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒâ€‹ÏIâ€‹T+1+Ïƒ2T)ğ’ªğœğœŒğ¼ğ‘‡1superscriptğœ2ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sigma\rho}{\sqrt{IT}}+\frac{1+\sigma^{2}}{T}\right) for Tâ‰¥2â€‹Pğ‘‡2ğ‘ƒT\geq 2P, where all the other constants are ignored in the ğ’ªâ€‹(â‹…)ğ’ªâ‹…\mathcal{O}\left(\cdot\right) notation here. For full gradient descent with Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0, this convergence rate is improved to ğ’ªâ€‹(1T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}\right).

Interpreting Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~Î´2P\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) Using Variance. The condition for Î´~2â€‹(P)=0superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ0\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0 may be too stringent for some practical scenarios of FL. Next, we show that Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) can be expressed as the variance of client participation weights averaged over Pğ‘ƒP rounds. We first express Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) with d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2} by further bounding:

(â€‹13â€‹)â‰¤Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1N[qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0]2â€‹d2,italic-(13italic-)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptdelimited-[]Â¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡02superscriptğ‘‘2\displaystyle\textstyle\eqref{eq:deltaExpression}\leq N\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right]^{2}d^{2}, (15)

where we first use Jensenâ€™s inequality on the sum over nğ‘›n in (13), then move the term qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0Â¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}} to the outside of the norm, where we define qt0nÂ¯:=1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtnassignÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}:=\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n} for any nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, and afterwards bound â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±2\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2} by d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2} according to AssumptionÂ 3. We note that (7) holds if the RHS of (15) is upper bounded by Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P). Therefore, we can obtain Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) by analyzing the statistical properties of qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0Â¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}} and then choosing Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) to be equal to the RHS of (15).

In the following, we assume that Î¼t0subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0\mu_{t_{0}} is chosen such that Î¼t0=ğ”¼â€‹[qtn]subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\mu_{t_{0}}=\mathbb{E}\left[q_{t}^{n}\right] for all nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\} and tâˆˆ{t0,t0+1,â€¦,t0+Pâˆ’1}ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡01â€¦subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1t\in\{t_{0},t_{0}+1,\ldots,t_{0}+P-1\}. This implies that the mean participation weights of all the clients within the same cycle of Pğ‘ƒP rounds are equal. Note that this condition is the same as unbiased client sampling in existing works [8, 9, 18, 21, 22, 36], because we consider an unweighted average in (1) and any weighting is included in the local objective function Fnâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±F_{n}(\mathbf{x}). However, differently from these existing works, we do not assume independence here (we will only assume independence in a special case later). Under this condition, it is apparent that Varâ€‹(qt0nÂ¯)=ğ”¼â€‹[(qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2]VarÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡02\mathrm{Var}\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\right] is the variance of qtnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›q_{t}^{n} averaged over Pğ‘ƒP rounds, for any nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}. We immediately have the following result.

Proposition 4.4 (Ergodic participation).

If {qtn:âˆ€t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›for-allğ‘¡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is a mean-ergodic process for any nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, which means that limPâ†’âˆğ”¼â€‹[(qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2]=0subscriptâ†’ğ‘ƒğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡020\textstyle\lim_{P\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\right]=0 for any nğ‘›n and t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}, then there exists Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) such that limPâ†’âˆÎ´~2â€‹(P)=0subscriptâ†’ğ‘ƒsuperscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ0\lim_{P\rightarrow\infty}\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0 while satisfying (7) in expectation.

Next, we consider the class of stationary and strongly mixing processes. Informally, a random process is said to be strongly mixing with coefficient Î±â€‹(P)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒ\alpha(P) if the outcomes that are at least Pğ‘ƒP steps apart are nearly independent, where the distance between the joint probability distribution of the outcomes and their independent counterpart is at most Î±â€‹(P)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒ\alpha(P). See [2, Sec. 27] for a formal definition. A specific example of stationary and strongly mixing processes is finite-state irreducible and aperiodic Markov chains, which have an Î±â€‹(P)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒ\alpha(P) that exponentially decreases in Pğ‘ƒP [2, Thm. 8.9]. It is known that the following (generalized) central limit theorem holds for stationary and strongly mixing processes, where we adapt the result to our participation weights.

Lemma 4.5 ([2, Thm. 27.4]).

If {qtn:âˆ€t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›for-allğ‘¡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is stationary and strongly mixing with Î±â€‹(P)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Pâˆ’5)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘ƒ5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), for any nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, then qt0nÂ¯âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î¼t0,Ï…^2P)similar-toÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›ğ’©subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡0superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ƒ\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{t_{0}},\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P}\right) for any t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0} when Pâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ƒP\rightarrow\infty, where ğ’©â€‹(â‹…,â‹…)ğ’©â‹…â‹…\mathcal{N}(\cdot,\cdot) denotes the normal distribution and Ï…^2:=Varâ€‹(qt0n)+2â€‹âˆ‘p=1âˆCovâ€‹(qt0n,qt0+pn)assignsuperscript^ğœ2Varsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›2superscriptsubscriptğ‘1Covsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ğ‘›\hat{\upsilon}^{2}:=\mathrm{Var}(q_{t_{0}}^{n})+2\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}).

From the definition of strongly mixing, we know that Covâ€‹(qt0n,qt0+pn)Covsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ğ‘›\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}) in the definition of Ï…^2superscript^ğœ2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} approaches zero as pğ‘p gets large, hence âˆ‘p=1âˆCovâ€‹(qt0n,qt0+pn)superscriptsubscriptğ‘1Covsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ğ‘›\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}) converges to a finite value. When Pâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ƒP\rightarrow\infty and Î±â€‹(P)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Pâˆ’5)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘ƒ5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), LemmaÂ 4.5 shows that Varâ€‹(qt0nÂ¯)=Ï…^2PVarÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ƒ\mathrm{Var}\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)=\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P}. Chebyshevâ€™s inequality gives

Prâ¡{(qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2â‰¤Ï…^2câ€‹P}â‰¥1âˆ’c.PrsuperscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡02superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ğ‘ƒ1ğ‘\displaystyle\textstyle\Pr\left\{\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\leq\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP}\right\}\geq 1-c. (16)

Plugging Varâ€‹(qt0nÂ¯)=ğ”¼â€‹[(qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2]=Ï…^2PVarÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğ”¼absentdelimited-[]superscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡02superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ƒ\mathrm{Var}\!\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)\!=\!\mathbb{E}_{\!\!}\left[\!\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\!-\!\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{\!2}\right]\!=\!\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P} and (qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2â‰¤Ï…^2câ€‹PsuperscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡02superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ğ‘ƒ\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\!-\!\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\!\leq\!\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP} into the RHS of (15) gives the following expected and high-probability results, respectively, where â€œw.p.â€ stands for â€œwith probabilityâ€.

Proposition 4.6 (Stationary and strongly mixing participation).

If {qtn:âˆ€t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›for-allğ‘¡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is stationary and strongly mixing with Î±â€‹(P)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Pâˆ’5)ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘ƒ5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), for any nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, then as Pâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ƒP\rightarrow\infty:
Choosing Î´~2â€‹(P)=N2â€‹d2â€‹Ï…^2Psuperscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘‘2superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P} satisfies (7) in expectation; Î´~2â€‹(P)=N2â€‹d2â€‹Ï…^2câ€‹Psuperscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘‘2superscript^ğœ2ğ‘ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP} satisfies (7) w.p. 1âˆ’c1ğ‘1-c.

For independent participation, we can obtain a similar result while not requiring Pâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ƒP\rightarrow\infty. Assuming that Varâ€‹(qtn)â‰¤Ï…2Varsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\mathrm{Var}(q_{t}^{n})\leq\upsilon^{2} for any tğ‘¡t and nğ‘›n, it is evident that Varâ€‹(qt0nÂ¯)â‰¤Ï…2PVarÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›superscriptğœ2ğ‘ƒ\mathrm{Var}\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)\leq\frac{\upsilon^{2}}{P}, because the variance of the sum of independent random variables is equal to the sum of the variance, and Varâ€‹(aâ€‹Z)=a2â€‹Varâ€‹(Z)Varğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘2Varğ‘\mathrm{Var}(aZ)=a^{2}\mathrm{Var}(Z), for an arbitrary constant ağ‘a and random variableÂ Zğ‘Z. We note that Hoeffdingâ€™s inequality [16] gives

Prâ¡{(qt0nÂ¯âˆ’Î¼t0)2â‰¤lnâ¡(2/c)2â€‹P}â‰¥1âˆ’c.PrsuperscriptÂ¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡subscriptğ‘¡022ğ‘2ğ‘ƒ1ğ‘\displaystyle\textstyle\Pr\left\{\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\leq\frac{\ln\left(\nicefrac{{2}}{{c}}\right)}{2P}\right\}\geq 1-c. (17)

We have the following result by plugging into the RHS ofÂ (15).

Proposition 4.7 (Independent participation).

If {qtn:âˆ€t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›for-allğ‘¡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is independent across tğ‘¡t, for any nğ‘›n, then:
Choosing Î´~2â€‹(P)=N2â€‹d2â€‹Ï…2Psuperscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptğœ2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\upsilon^{2}}{P} satisfies (7) in expectation; Î´~2â€‹(P)=N2â€‹d2â€‹lnâ¡(2/c)2â€‹Psuperscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘‘22ğ‘2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\ln\left(\nicefrac{{2}}{{c}}\right)}{2P} satisfies (7) w.p. 1âˆ’c1ğ‘1\!-\!c.

Note that the independence here is only assumed across tğ‘¡t, so qtnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›q_{t}^{n} and qtnâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²q_{t}^{n^{\prime}} for the same tğ‘¡t but nâ‰ nâ€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›â€²n\neq n^{\prime} can still be dependent of each other. Compared to PropositionÂ 4.6, the high-probability bound in PropositionÂ 4.7 has cğ‘c in the logarithmic term, which is tighter since 12â€‹lnâ¡(2c)â‰¤1câˆ’12122ğ‘1ğ‘12\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{2}{c}\right)\leq\frac{1}{c}-\frac{1}{2} (ignoring Ï…^2superscript^ğœ2\hat{\upsilon}^{2}).

Choosing PPP as a Function of TTT. The choices of Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in PropositionsÂ 4.6 and 4.7 include Pğ‘ƒP in the denominator. Hence, we can guarantee convergence to zero error if we choose Pğ‘ƒP to be an increasing function of Tğ‘‡T, which also ensures that Pâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ƒP\rightarrow\infty as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty. If we choose PâˆN52â€‹Iâ€‹Tproportional-toğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘52ğ¼ğ‘‡P\propto N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT}, we can obtain the following convergence rate from CorollaryÂ 3.3 together with PropositionÂ 4.1.

Corollary 4.8 (Stochastic participation).

If the conditions of either PropositionÂ 4.6 or PropositionÂ 4.7 hold, and we choose P=Ï…^2â€‹N52â€‹Iâ€‹Tğ‘ƒsuperscript^ğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¼ğ‘‡P=\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT} or P=Ï…2â€‹N52â€‹Iâ€‹Tğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¼ğ‘‡P=\upsilon^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT}, respectively, and the learning rates according to CorollaryÂ 3.3, then the convergence error in expectation over ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} satisfies

mintâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2]subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\min_{t}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right] â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Ïƒ2)â€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹â„±Iâ€‹T+d2Nâ€‹Iâ€‹T+d2+Ïƒ2T),absentğ’ª1superscriptğœ2ğœŒğ¿â„±ğ¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptğœ2ğ‘‡\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{(1+\sigma^{2})\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}+\frac{d^{2}}{\sqrt{NIT}}+\frac{d^{2}+\sigma^{2}}{T}\Bigg{)}, (18)

for Iâ‰¤ÏÏ…^2â€‹N5/2â€‹Lâ€‹â„±ğ¼ğœŒsuperscript^ğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¿â„±I\leq\frac{\rho}{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} and Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty when using conditions of PropositionÂ 4.6, or Iâ‰¤ÏÏ…2â€‹N5/2â€‹Lâ€‹â„±ğ¼ğœŒsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¿â„±I\leq\frac{\rho}{\upsilon^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} and Tâ‰¥4â€‹Ï…4â€‹Iâ€‹N5ğ‘‡4superscriptğœ4ğ¼superscriptğ‘5T\geq 4\upsilon^{4}IN^{5} when using condition of PropositionÂ 4.7.

Remark. Although the upper bound of Iğ¼I in CorollaryÂ 4.8 may appear restrictive, note that the optimal solution ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\mathbf{x}^{*} to (1) remains the same when the objective fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±f(\mathbf{x}) is scaled by a multiplicative positive constant, which in turn scales Lâ€‹â„±ğ¿â„±\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}. More specifically, consider an arbitrary a>0ğ‘0a>0, we define Fâ€²â€‹(ğ±):=aâ€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±)assignsuperscriptğ¹â€²ğ±ğ‘ğ¹ğ±F^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}):=aF(\mathbf{x}) and fâ€²â€‹(ğ±):=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1NFnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)=aâ€‹fâ€‹(ğ±)assignsuperscriptğ‘“â€²ğ±1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ¹â€²ğ‘›ğ±ğ‘ğ‘“ğ±f^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{x})=af(\mathbf{x}). Then, we have fâ€²â€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâ€²â£âˆ—=aâ€‹fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’aâ€‹fâˆ—=aâ€‹â„±superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptğ±0superscriptğ‘“â€²ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ±0ğ‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘â„±f^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{\prime*}=af(\mathbf{x}_{0})-af^{*}=a\mathcal{F}. We also have â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fnâ€²â€‹(ğ²)â€–=aâ€‹â€–âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fnâ€‹(ğ²)â€–â‰¤aâ€‹Lâ€‹â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ²â€–normâˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¹â€²ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¹â€²ğ‘›ğ²ğ‘normâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘›ğ²ğ‘ğ¿normğ±ğ²\left\|\nabla F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|=a\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|\leq aL\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\| from AssumptionÂ 1, due to the linearity of gradients. Hence, by choosing aâˆˆ(0,1)ğ‘01a\in(0,1) and replacing Fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ¹ğ±F(\mathbf{x}) with Fâ€²â€‹(ğ±)superscriptğ¹â€²ğ±F^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}), we can make Lâ€‹â„±ğ¿â„±\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}} arbitrarily small and ÏÏ…^2â€‹N5/2â€‹Lâ€‹â„±ğœŒsuperscript^ğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¿â„±\frac{\rho}{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} or ÏÏ…2â€‹N5/2â€‹Lâ€‹â„±ğœŒsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ¿â„±\frac{\rho}{\upsilon^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} (the upper bound ofÂ Iğ¼I in CorollaryÂ 4.8) arbitrarily large without affecting the optimal solution ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\mathbf{x}^{*}. Thus, we can potentially allow arbitrarily large Iğ¼I by scaling fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±f(\mathbf{x}) without changing the optimal solution ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\mathbf{x}^{*}. We leave the in-depth study of this phenomenon for future work, where we recognize that such a scaling will affect the LHS of the convergence bound too, although the optimal solution ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\mathbf{x}^{*} does not change.

We also give the following further insight related to CorollaryÂ 4.8. In CorollaryÂ 4.8, we choose Pğ‘ƒP to be proportional to the variance Ï…^2superscript^ğœ2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} or Ï…2superscriptğœ2\upsilon^{2}. This is intuitive because when the clientsâ€™ participation weights have higher variance, we would like to wait for more rounds before amplifying, so that the contributions of clients are more balanced. In the same way, Pğ‘ƒP increases with the number of clients Nğ‘N. Recall that âˆ‘n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1. Intuitively, when the participation patterns of individual clients remain â€œunchangedâ€, qtnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›q_{t}^{n} scales with 1N1ğ‘\frac{1}{N} and its variance Ï…^2superscript^ğœ2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} or Ï…2superscriptğœ2\upsilon^{2} scales with 1N21superscriptğ‘2\frac{1}{N^{2}}, so the product Ï…^2â€‹N52âˆ¼Nsimilar-tosuperscript^ğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ‘\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sim\sqrt{N} or Ï…2â€‹N52âˆ¼Nsimilar-tosuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘52ğ‘\upsilon^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sim\sqrt{N}, implying that Pğ‘ƒP effectively scales with Nğ‘\sqrt{N} when this intuition holds.

While the result in CorollaryÂ 4.8 is in expectation, the high-probability bound is similar (see TableÂ 1). In general, since (7) is used as an upper bound in the proof of TheoremÂ 3.1, if Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is chosen so that (7) holds in expectation or with a certain probability, such as in PropositionsÂ 4.4, 4.6 and 4.7, then the final convergence result also holds in expectation or with a certain probability, respectively.

5 Discussions and Insights

Interpretation of â€œLinear Speedupâ€. Linear speedup is a desirable property seen in existing works that consider idealized client participation [39, 40, 36]. It essence, it means that the same convergence error can be achieved by increasing the number of participating clients Sğ‘†S (with Sâ‰¤Nğ‘†ğ‘S\leq N) and reducing the number of rounds Tğ‘‡T, while keeping the product Sâ€‹Tğ‘†ğ‘‡ST unchanged. In our case of arbitrary client participation, the coefficient ÏğœŒ\rho is a generalization of the 1/S1ğ‘†\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S}}} term for linear speedup in existing works that select a fixed number of Sğ‘†S clients in each round. When Sğ‘†S clients participate with equal weight, because âˆ‘n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1, we have qtn=1/Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›1ğ‘†q_{t}^{n}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{S}} for the participating clients and qtn=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›0q_{t}^{n}=0 for the non-participating clients, so Ï=[âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2]1/2=1/SğœŒsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›2121ğ‘†\rho=\big{[}\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\big{]}^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S}}}. Plugging this ÏğœŒ\rho back to the convergence results, we achieve a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğ’ªğœğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) in CorollaryÂ 4.3 and ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Ïƒ2)/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğ’ª1superscriptğœ2ğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{(1+\sigma^{2})}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) in CorollaryÂ 4.8, for sufficiently large Tğ‘‡T while ignoring the other variables in ğ’ªâ€‹(â‹…)ğ’ªâ‹…\mathcal{O}(\cdot), as shown in TableÂ 1. This shows that we can achieve linear speedup in Sğ‘†S in this special case. We can also generalize to having at least Sminsubscriptğ‘†minS_{\mathrm{min}} clients participating with equal weight in each round. Following the same argument, we have Ïâ‰¤1/SminğœŒ1subscriptğ‘†min\rho\leq\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S_{\mathrm{min}}}}} in this case, giving a linear speedup in Sminsubscriptğ‘†minS_{\mathrm{min}}. In general, we achieve a linear speedup factor of 1/Ï21superscriptğœŒ2\nicefrac{{1}}{{\rho^{2}}} in the case of arbitrary participation.

Matching Lower Bound or State-of-the-Art Results. We continue to assume sufficiently large Tğ‘‡T. For regularized participation (CorollaryÂ 4.3), our convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğ’ªğœğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) matches the lower bound of convergence error for centralized SGD [1]. The lower bound states that to reach a convergence error of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, there exists an objective function such that at least Î©â€‹(Ïƒ2/Ïµ2)Î©superscriptğœ2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\Omega\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{\epsilon^{2}}}\right) stochastic gradient oracle calls are required.222Note that [1] defines the convergence error as â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–normâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\| whereas we define it as â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}. Hence, the order of our Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is different from that in [1]. We have Sâ€‹Iâ€‹Tğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡SIT oracle calls to reach Ïµ=ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)italic-Ïµğ’ªğœğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\epsilon=\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) according to our result, thus our upper bound matches this lower bound and is asymptotically optimal. Note that our upper bound still matches the lower bound if we include the coefficient Lâ€‹â„±ğ¿â„±\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}} in ğ’ªâ€‹(â‹…)ğ’ªâ‹…\mathcal{O}\left(\cdot\right) and Lâ€‹â„±ğ¿â„±L\mathcal{F} in Î©â€‹(â‹…)Î©â‹…\Omega\left(\cdot\right). For stochastic participation (CorollaryÂ 4.8), our convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹((1+Ïƒ2)/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğ’ª1superscriptğœ2ğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{(1+\sigma^{2})}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) matches state-of-the-art results of FedAvg [8, 18, 36] that were obtained for the more idealized case of clients being selected to participate according to a specific independent sampling scheme.

Special Case of Waiting for All Clients. We consider a specific configuration of FedAvg where all the clients wait for Pğ‘ƒP rounds before proceeding with SGD. In every iteration iğ‘–i of round tğ‘¡t within these Pğ‘ƒP rounds, each participating client nğ‘›n may call the stochastic gradient oracle to obtain ğ nâ€‹(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}), but it does not perform local updates. Instead, it accumulates and averages the sampled instances of ğ nâ€‹(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}). SGD is performed once after these Pğ‘ƒP rounds using the average ğ nâ€‹(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) from each client nğ‘›n. Assume that Pğ‘ƒP is large enough so that each client nğ‘›n computes ğ nâ€‹(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) at least Mâ‰¥1ğ‘€1M\geq 1 times that are averaged afterwards. If the Mğ‘€M instances of ğ nâ€‹(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) are all independent from each other, the noise Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} (defined in AssumptionÂ 2) becomes Ïƒ2/Msuperscriptğœ2ğ‘€\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{M}}. This configuration can be considered as a special case of AlgorithmÂ 1, where all Nğ‘N clients perform SGD once in Pğ‘ƒP rounds, so there are T/Pğ‘‡ğ‘ƒ\nicefrac{{T}}{{P}} updates in total, with a reduced stochastic gradient noise of Ïƒ2/Msuperscriptğœ2ğ‘€\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{M}}. By replacing Ïƒğœ\sigma and Sâ€‹Iâ€‹Tğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡SIT in our bound ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ/Sâ€‹Iâ€‹T)ğ’ªğœğ‘†ğ¼ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) with Ïƒ/Mğœğ‘€\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{M}}} and Nâ€‹T/Pğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒ\nicefrac{{NT}}{{P}}, respectively, we obtain a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒâ€‹P/Mâ€‹Nâ€‹T)ğ’ªğœğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma\sqrt{P}}}{{\sqrt{MNT}}}\right) for regularized participation with this â€œwait-for-allâ€ method.

In theory, when considering regularized participation and Mğ‘€M is large enough, the convergence rate of this â€œwait-for-allâ€ method can potentially match with that of the original configuration of AlgorithmÂ 1. In this way, the convergence error upper bound of both methods can match the lower bound of SGD convergence error (see discussion above). However, in practice, reducing the stochastic gradient noise as in this â€œwait-for-allâ€ method may only give limited improvement. One reason is that practical settings have a finite number of training data samples, so the noise can only be reduced by a certain degree. In addition, having some noise in SGD can prevent the model parameter from being trapped in saddle points and local minima in practice. The empirical results in SectionÂ 6 show that AlgorithmÂ 1 with amplification performs better than waiting for all the clients. We also note that our results for stochastic participation (CorollaryÂ 4.8) does not require all the clients to participate within Pğ‘ƒP rounds.

Achieving Regularized Participation in Practice. In theory, regularized participation requires that 1Pâ€‹âˆ‘t=t0t0+Pâˆ’1qtn1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n} is equal to each other for all the clients nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, for a properly chosenÂ Pğ‘ƒP. When all the clients are connected to the system and client sampling is performed to limit the computation and communication overhead, this condition holds when the clients are selected according to a permutation, i.e., all the clients participate once before the same client can be selected again. In the case where clients get disconnected from time to time, the system can try to properly schedule the participation of connected clients and their weights {qtn}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›\{q_{t}^{n}\}, so that within a cycle of Pğ‘ƒP rounds, all the clients participate with equal averaged weights. In practice, it can be sufficient if this regularized condition is only approximately satisfied, especially when multiple clients have similar datasets so that Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is small although not necessarily zero. The empirical results in SectionÂ 6 show that AlgorithmÂ 1 with amplification can give good performance even if Pğ‘ƒP is less than the participation cycle of all clients. This suggests that, as long as the subset of clients that participate in Pğ‘ƒP rounds are more representative of the overall data distribution than the (usually much smaller) subset of clients that participate in a single round, amplifying the updates every Pğ‘ƒP rounds can be useful.

6 Experiments

We ran experiments of training convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with FashionMNISTÂ [34] and CIFAR-10Â [19] datasets, each of which has images in 101010 different classes. We set the total number of clients to N=250ğ‘250N=250. Similar to existing worksÂ [36, 6, 7], we partition the data into clients so that each client has data of one majority class label, with 5%percent55\% of data of other (minority) labels, to simulate a setup with non-IID data distribution which is often encountered in FL scenarios. We assume that the clientsâ€™ availability exhibits a periodic pattern inspired byÂ [6, 7]. Namely, in the first 100100100 rounds, only clients with the first two majority labels are available; in the next 100100100 rounds, only clients with the next two majority labels are available, and so on. In each round, S=10ğ‘†10S=10 clients participate in a regularized manner, out of all the currently available clients. To speed up initial rounds of training, similar to practical deep learning implementations, we start with standard FedAvg with a relatively large initial learning rate. The initial rates are Î³=0.1ğ›¾0.1\gamma=0.1 and Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05 without amplification (i.e., Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1) for FashionMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively, which were obtained using grid search in a separate scenario of always participation. After an initial training of 2,00020002,000 rounds for FashionMNIST and 4,00040004,000 rounds for CIFAR-10, we study the performance of different approaches with their own learning rates. Additional setup details and results are given in AppendixÂ D.

Comparing Different Methods. We show the results of AlgorithmÂ 1 both with and without amplification. When using amplification, we set Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10 and P=500ğ‘ƒ500P=500. We also compare to an algorithm that waits for all the clients, related to our discussion in SectionÂ 5, for two settings where each client computes its gradients either on a minibatch or on the entire dataset, which we refer to as â€œwait-minibatchâ€ and â€œwait-fullâ€, respectively. The best learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma of each approach was separately found on a grid that is {1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001}10.10.010.0010.0001\{1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001\} times the initial learning rate, with the periodic participation pattern described above. The results are shown in FigureÂ 1.

We make a few key observations as follows. First, we clearly see that AlgorithmÂ 1 with amplification gives the best performance. By choosing P=500ğ‘ƒ500P=500, we match with the participation period of clients, as described in the setup above. This corresponds to our setting with regularized participation. In this case, AlgorithmÂ 1 with amplification allows different groups of clients to make small progress among themselves first. After Pğ‘ƒP rounds, each client has made its own share of contribution, and the updates get amplified so that the model parameter progresses faster towards the direction that is overall beneficial for all the clients. As our theory predicts, this approach gives a desirable convergence rate, which is now verified by experiments. Next, we observe that the â€œwait-minibatchâ€ and â€œwait-fullâ€ methods perform worse than AlgorithmÂ 1 with amplification. We also observe that â€œwait-fullâ€, which computes the gradient on the entire dataset, does not provide substantial gain compared to â€œwait-minibatchâ€ in the experiments. These observations align with our discussion in SectionÂ 5 on the practical performance of different methods. Finally, we observe that standard FedAvg (i.e., AlgorithmÂ 1 without amplification) gives the lowest performance. This is because without amplification, the algorithm cannot put more emphasis on the collective updates by the cohort of all clients, and the parameter updates may diverge from the overall optimal direction.

Different Values of Pğ‘ƒP. Next, we fix Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10 in AlgorithmÂ 1 and study the effect of choosing different values of Pğ‘ƒP. We use the same learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma that is obtained from grid search in the previous experiment. Note that the clientsâ€™ availability pattern remains the same as described above. The choice of different Pğ‘ƒP simulates the practical scenario where the estimation of Pğ‘ƒP may not perfectly align with the actual participation cycle. The results are shown in FigureÂ 2.

We observe that P=1ğ‘ƒ1P=1, which corresponds to the â€œclassicalâ€ setting of FedAvg with two-sided learning rates [18, 36], does not give the best performance. Interestingly, compared to P=500ğ‘ƒ500P=500, we see that P=100ğ‘ƒ100P=100 and P=300ğ‘ƒ300P=300 give a similar performance, and even slightly better performance in the case of CIFAR-10 data. Due to the random offset applied to the first participation cycle in each experiment (see AppendixÂ D.1 for details), every interval of 100100100 rounds can include the â€œpartialâ€ contributions by two subsets of clients (with data in 444, out of 101010, majority classes). The results suggest that amplifying such partial contributions by multiple subsets of clients can still improve performance. In the case of CIFAR-10 data, the reason for P=500ğ‘ƒ500P=500 being slightly worse may be that the accumulated update within Pğ‘ƒP rounds generally becomes larger as Pğ‘ƒP gets larger, in which case amplification causes a bigger change in the model parameter. Depending on the landscape of the loss function, this change may be too big so that the model performance decreases. For a similar reason, the performances of P=700ğ‘ƒ700P=700 and P=900ğ‘ƒ900P=900 are even worse. Nevertheless, we expect that choosing a smaller learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma can improve the performance for large Pğ‘ƒP values.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied FL with arbitrary client participation. For a generalized FedAvg algorithm that amplifies parameter updates every Pğ‘ƒP rounds, we have developed a unified framework for convergence analysis and obtained convergence rates for a variety of client participation patterns. Our findings suggest that regularized participation with finite Pğ‘ƒP gives the best performance and matches the lower bound of SGD convergence error when Tğ‘‡T is sufficiently large. For stochastic participation, first, we have formally proven that convergence is guaranteed when the participation process is ergodic. Then, for two generic classes of participation processes, we have proven that with a properly chosen Pğ‘ƒP, our convergence rate matches state-of-the-art FedAvg convergence rates that were derived for the idealized case of independent and unbiased participation. The empirical results have confirmed that amplification is useful and also provided further insights. Future directions include analysis of advanced FL algorithms and more detailed empirical study.
