â‰¤4â€‹(ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0)]âˆ’ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0+P)])Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹P+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹(6â€‹Iâ€‹Î½~2+Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2))\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\left(\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}+P})\right]\right)}{\gamma\eta IP}+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}I\left(6I\tilde{\nu}^{2}+\sigma^{2}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)\right)
+6â€‹L2â€‹(3â€‹Î³2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+24â€‹Î³2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+3â€‹Î³2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹[Ï2+16â€‹Pâ€‹(1âˆ’âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2)])6superscriptğ¿23superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¼2superscript~ğœˆ224superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğ‘ƒ2superscript~ğ›½23superscriptğ›¾2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2delimited-[]superscriptğœŒ216ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›2\displaystyle\quad+6L^{2}\left(3\gamma^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+24\gamma^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+3\gamma^{2}IP\sigma^{2}\left[\rho^{2}+\frac{1}{6P}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)\right]\right)
+6â€‹Î´~2â€‹(P)+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2â€‹Ïƒ26superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ2ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\quad+6\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)+2\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\sigma^{2}
=4â€‹(ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0)]âˆ’ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0+P)])Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹P+126â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+144â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+6â€‹Î´~2â€‹(P)\displaystyle=\frac{4\left(\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}+P})\right]\right)}{\gamma\eta IP}+126\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+144\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+6\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)
+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2)+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹[Ï2+16â€‹Pâ€‹(1âˆ’âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2)]+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2â€‹Ïƒ218superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼superscriptğœ21superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›218superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2delimited-[]superscriptğœŒ216ğ‘ƒ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›22ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\quad+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}I\sigma^{2}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\sigma^{2}\left[\rho^{2}+\frac{1}{6P}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)\right]+2\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\sigma^{2}
=4â€‹(ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0)]âˆ’ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0+P)])Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹P+126â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+144â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+6â€‹Î´~2â€‹(P)\displaystyle=\frac{4\left(\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}+P})\right]\right)}{\gamma\eta IP}+126\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+144\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+6\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)
+21â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1âˆ’âˆ‘n=1N(qtn)2)+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹Ï2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2â€‹Ïƒ221superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼superscriptğœ21superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›218superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœŒ22ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\quad+21\gamma^{2}L^{2}I\sigma^{2}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\sigma^{2}\rho^{2}+2\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\sigma^{2}
â‰¤4â€‹(ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0)]âˆ’ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t0+P)])Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹P+126â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+144â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+6â€‹Î´~2â€‹(P)\displaystyle\leq\frac{4\left(\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right]-\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}+P})\right]\right)}{\gamma\eta IP}+126\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+144\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+6\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)
+(21â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ï2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2)â€‹Ïƒ2.21superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼18superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœŒ22ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\quad+\left(21\gamma^{2}L^{2}I+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\rho^{2}+2\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\right)\sigma^{2}. (C.16)

We now have

mintâ¡ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2]\displaystyle\min_{t}\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right]
â‰¤mint0âˆˆ{0,P,2â€‹P,â€¦,(âŒŠTPâŒ‹âˆ’1)â€‹P}â¡ğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t0)â€–2]\displaystyle\leq\min_{t_{0}\in\left\{0,P,2P,...,\left(\left\lfloor\frac{T}{P}\right\rfloor-1\right)P\right\}}\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right\|^{2}\right]
â‰¤1âŒŠT/PâŒ‹â‹…âˆ‘t0=0,P,2â€‹P,â€¦,(âŒŠTPâŒ‹âˆ’1)â€‹Pğ”¼â‹…|ğ’¬â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t0)â€–2]\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\left\lfloor\nicefrac{{T}}{{P}}\right\rfloor}\cdot\sum_{{t_{0}}=0,P,2P,...,\left(\left\lfloor\frac{T}{P}\right\rfloor-1\right)P}\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}})\right\|^{2}\right]
â‰¤(a)â€‹8â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâˆ—)Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹T+126â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+144â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+6â€‹Î´~2â€‹(P)ğ‘8ğ‘“subscriptğ±0superscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¼ğ‘‡126superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscript~ğœˆ2144superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğ‘ƒ2superscript~ğ›½26superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle\overset{(a)}{\leq}\frac{8\left(f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{*}\right)}{\gamma\eta IT}+126\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+144\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+6\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)
+(21â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I+18â€‹Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ï2+2â€‹Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2)â€‹Ïƒ221superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼18superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœŒ22ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\quad\quad+\left(21\gamma^{2}L^{2}I+18\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\rho^{2}+2\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\right)\sigma^{2}
=ğ’ªâ€‹(â„±Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Iâ€‹T+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹Î½~2+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I2â€‹P2â€‹Î²~2+Î´~2â€‹(P)+(Î³2â€‹L2â€‹I+Î³2â€‹L2â€‹Iâ€‹Pâ€‹Ï2+Î³â€‹Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ï2)â€‹Ïƒ2)absentğ’ªâ„±ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscript~ğœˆ2superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ¼2superscriptğ‘ƒ2superscript~ğ›½2superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğ¿2ğ¼ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœŒ2ğ›¾ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\mathcal{F}}{\gamma\eta IT}+\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}\tilde{\nu}^{2}+\gamma^{2}L^{2}I^{2}P^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)+\left(\gamma^{2}L^{2}I+\gamma^{2}L^{2}IP\rho^{2}+\gamma\eta L\rho^{2}\right)\sigma^{2}\right)

where the first term in (a)ğ‘(a) is from telescoping of (C.16) and 1âŒŠT/PâŒ‹â€‹Pâ‰¤1(T/Pâˆ’1)â€‹P=1Tâˆ’Pâ‰¤1Tâˆ’T/2=2T1ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒ1ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒ1ğ‘ƒ1ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒ1ğ‘‡ğ‘‡22ğ‘‡\frac{1}{\left\lfloor\nicefrac{{T}}{{P}}\right\rfloor P}\leq\frac{1}{\left(\nicefrac{{T}}{{P}}-1\right)P}=\frac{1}{T-P}\leq\frac{1}{T-\nicefrac{{T}}{{2}}}=\frac{2}{T} since Pâ‰¤T2ğ‘ƒğ‘‡2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, and the other terms in (a)ğ‘(a) are constants independent of t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}. âˆ

C.4 Proof of CorollariesÂ 3.2 and 3.3

For CorollaryÂ 3.2, we note that Î³â€‹Î·=minâ¡{â„±Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹T;1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹P}ğ›¾ğœ‚â„±ğœğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\eta=\min\left\{\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}};\frac{1}{LIP}\right\} by the choice of Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î·ğœ‚\eta. Because Î³â‰¤112â€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pğ›¾112ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\leq\frac{1}{12LIP} (since Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1) and Î³â€‹Î·â‰¤1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pğ›¾ğœ‚1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\eta\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, the conditions of TheoremÂ 3.1 hold. Then, using Î³â€‹Î·â‰¤â„±Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tğ›¾ğœ‚â„±ğœğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡\gamma\eta\leq\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}, 1Î³â€‹Î·=maxâ¡{Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tâ„±;Lâ€‹Iâ€‹P}â‰¤Ïƒâ€‹Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tâ„±+Lâ€‹Iâ€‹P1ğ›¾ğœ‚ğœğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡â„±ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒğœğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡â„±ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\frac{1}{\gamma\eta}=\max\left\{\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}};LIP\right\}\leq\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}+LIP, and Ï2â‰¤1superscriptğœŒ21\rho^{2}\leq 1, we obtain the result.

For CorollaryÂ 3.3, we have Î³â€‹Î·=â„±Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tğ›¾ğœ‚â„±ğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡\gamma\eta=\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}} according to the choice of Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î·ğœ‚\eta. Because â„±Ïâ€‹Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Tâ‰¤1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pâ„±ğœŒğ¿ğ¼ğ‘‡1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}}\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, we have Î³â€‹Î·â‰¤1Lâ€‹Iâ€‹Pğ›¾ğœ‚1ğ¿ğ¼ğ‘ƒ\gamma\eta\leq\frac{1}{LIP} and the conditions of TheoremÂ 3.1 hold. The result is obtained by plugging the values of Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î·ğœ‚\eta into the result in TheoremÂ 3.1, and noting that Ï2â‰¤1superscriptğœŒ21\rho^{2}\leq 1 in the last term. âˆ

Appendix D Additional Details and Results of Experiments

D.1 Additional Details of the Setup

Code. Please visit https://shiqiang.wang/code/fl-arbitrary-participation

Datasets. The FashionMNIST dataset333https://github.com/zalandoresearch/fashion-mnist has MIT license and a citation requirement [34]. The CIFAR-10 dataset444https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~kriz/cifar.html only has a citation requirement [19]. We have cited both papers in our main paper. Our experiments used the original split of training and test data in each dataset, where the training data is further split into workers in a non-IID manner according to the labels of data samples with a similarity of 5%percent55\%, as described in the main paper.

Motivation of the Setup. The non-IID splitting of data to clients and the periodic connectivity are motivated by application scenarios of FL. An example of a real-world scenario is where different geographically-dispersed user groups can participate in training at different times of the day, e.g., when their phones are charging during the night. Another example is where multiple organizations have their local servers (also known as edge servers), which can participate in training only when their servers are idle, such as during the night when there are few user requests, and these servers are located in different geographical regions. Our notion of â€œclientâ€ is a general term that can stand for the phone or the local server in these specific scenarios.

Availability of Clients. In the case of periodically available clients, as described in the main paper, subsets of clients with different majority class labels take turns to become available. For example, only those clients with the first two majority classes of data are available in the first 100100100 rounds; then, in the next 100100100 rounds, only those clients with the next two majority classes of data are available, and so on. The majority class of each client is determined by the non-IID data partitioning. There are 101010 classes in total, so a full cycle of participation of all clients is 500500500 rounds. To avoid inherent synchronicity across different simulation instances, we apply a random offset in the participation cycle at the beginning of the FL process. With this random offset, the number of rounds where the first subset of clients participate can be decreased to less than 100100100. For example, the first subset of clients may participate for 373737 rounds (an arbitrary number that is less than or equal to 100100100), the second subset of clients then participates for the next 100100100 rounds, and so on. This random offset varies across different simulation instances. It represents the practical scenario where the FL process can start at any time in the day. In each round, S=10ğ‘†10S=10 clients are selected to participate, according to a random permutation among the currently available clients. The selection of a small number of clients among the available clients can be due to resource efficiency considerations, for instance.

In addition to periodic availability, we also consider a setting where all the N=250ğ‘250N=250 clients are always available, and a subset of S=10ğ‘†10S=10 clients are selected to participate in each round. Here, we consider two participation patterns. For independent participation, the subset of clients are selected randomly according to a uniform distribution, independently across rounds. For regularized participation, the clients are first randomly permuted and then Sğ‘†S clients are selected sequentially from the permuted sequence of clients, so that all the Nğ‘N clients participate in FL once in every NSğ‘ğ‘†\frac{N}{S} rounds.

Hyperparameter Choices. The initial local learning rates of Î³=0.1ğ›¾0.1\gamma=0.1 and Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05 for FashionMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively, were obtained from a learning rate search where the model was trained using Î³âˆˆ{0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001}ğ›¾0.50.10.050.010.0050.0010.00050.0001\gamma\in\{0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001\} while fixing Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1. We considered the case of always available clients for this learning rate search. We chose the learning rate that gave the smallest training loss after 2,00020002,000 rounds of training for FashionMNIST and 4,00040004,000 rounds of training for CIFAR-10, where we observed that the best learning rate is the same for both independent and regularized participation with each dataset. The reason of considering always available clients for tuning the initial learning rates is because this is the ideal case which allows the model to make big steps in training, so it is reasonable to use these learning rates as starting points even in the case of periodic availability. The number of rounds that use the initial learning rate in the case of periodic availability was determined so that the modelâ€™s performance no longer improves substantially afterwards, if keeping the same initial learning rate.

The subsequent learning rates for the methods shown in Figure 1, with periodically available clients, are found from a search on a grid that is {1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001}10.10.010.0010.0001\{1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001\} times the initial learning rate, as described in the main paper. The optimal learning rates found from this search are shown in TableÂ D.1.

We fix the number of local updates to I=5ğ¼5I=5 and use a minibatch size of 161616 for local SGD at each participating client. These parameters were not tuned specifically, since the relative difference between different methods will likely follow the same trend for different Iğ¼I and minibatch sizes. Because Iğ¼I is a controllable parameter in our experiments, we consider a minor extension (compared to our discussion in SectionÂ 5) in the â€œwait-*â€ methods in our experiments, where each client performs Iğ¼I local iterations (instead of one iteration in the discussion in SectionÂ 5) before starting to wait. The intuition remains the same as what has been discussed in SectionÂ 5. The reason for this extension is because the â€œwait-*â€ methods defined in this way is equivalent to the case where all the clients are available but the total number of rounds is reduced by Pğ‘ƒP, so it has an easily interpretable meaning in practice. In addition, changing Iğ¼I can change the performance of all methods (including AlgorithmÂ 1, both with and without amplification, and the â€œwait-*â€ methods), while their relative difference can remain similar. We do not study the effect of Iğ¼I and minibatch size in details in this work.

Model Architecture. The CNN architectures used in our experiments are shown in TableÂ D.2, where we use Kaiming initialization [15] for all the ReLU layers. All convolutional and dense layers, except for the last layer, use ReLU activation.

Collecting Results. The plots in Figures 1â€“2 and all the figures showing additional results in the next section were obtained from simulations with 101010 different random seeds for FashionMNIST and 555 different random seeds for CIFAR-10. For the best viewing experience, we further applied moving average over a window length of 3%percent33\% of the data points (on the xğ‘¥x-axis) in the loss and accuracy results. In all the figures, the solid lines and the shaded areas show the average and standard deviation values, respectively, over the moving average window and all simulation runs for each configuration.

Computational Resources. The workload of experiments was split between a desktop machine with RTX 3070 GPU and an internal GPU cluster. On RTX 3070, the FashionMNIST experiment with 300,000300000300,000 training rounds takes about a day to complete for a single simulation instance; the CIFAR-10 experiment with 600,000600000600,000 training rounds takes about three days to complete for a single simulation instance. The RTX 3070 has memory that can support simulation with 555 different random seeds (i.e., 555 different instances) at the same time. On the internal GPU cluster, the running times are slightly shorter since it has better-performing GPUs. We also note that the â€œwait-*â€ methods run faster than AlgorithmÂ 1 in simulation because a lot of rounds are skipped, but this does not mean that they can train models faster in practice, because we consider the number of training rounds as an indication of physical time elapse. For example, in the case of periodic availability, each subset of clients is available for 100100100 rounds in a cycle. This means that 100100100 rounds of training can take place during the physical time duration that these clients are available. AlgorithmÂ 1 chooses to actually train models during this time. The â€œwait-*â€ methods choose not to train in some of the rounds, but they still need to wait until the time has passed and the next subset of clients becomes available, where the time here is measured by the number of training rounds that includes those rounds that may be skipped by the â€œwait-*â€ methods.

D.2 Additional Results

In the following, we present some additional results obtained from experiments.

D.2.1 Always Available Clients

We first consider the case of always available clients, where a subset of S=10ğ‘†10S=10 clients are selected in an independent or regularized manner, as discussed in SectionÂ D.1. We compare the results of independent and regularized participation in FigureÂ D.1. The observation is that both methods give similar performance, with regularized participation having a marginal performance improvement. As our theory predicts (see TableÂ 1), both independent and regularized participation can guarantee convergence, where regularized participation gives a slightly better convergence rate.

D.2.2 Periodically Available Clients

Different Learning Rates and Amplification Factors. Next, we consider periodically available clients as in the main paper. We study the performance of AlgorithmÂ 1 with different learning rate and amplification factor configurations. The results are shown in FiguresÂ D.2 and D.3.

FigureÂ D.2 shows the results with different combinations of the local learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma and amplification factor Î·ğœ‚\eta. We note that Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1 corresponds to the case without amplification and Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10 corresponds to the case with amplification (and with an amplification factor of 101010). We can observe that when Î³ğ›¾\gamma is large, the training is generally unstable with high fluctuation, high loss, and low accuracy. Reducing Î³ğ›¾\gamma improves the performance. According to our theory, P=500ğ‘ƒ500P=500 gives a small Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) with this experimental setup, because the cycle of all clients being available once is 500500500 rounds. On the other hand, a small Î´~2â€‹(P)superscript~ğ›¿2ğ‘ƒ\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) can be achieved with a much smaller Pğ‘ƒP in the case of always available clients (in SectionÂ D.2.1). When Pğ‘ƒP gets large, our theory suggests that the learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma should become small in order to guarantee convergence. This explains why non-convergence is observed in FigureÂ D.2 for large Î³ğ›¾\gamma, while convergence is observed for small Î³ğ›¾\gamma. For the smallest Î³ğ›¾\gamma in each case, i.e., Î³=10âˆ’5ğ›¾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5} for FashionMNIST and Î³=5Ã—10âˆ’6ğ›¾5superscript106\gamma=5\times 10^{-6} for CIFAR-10, we can see that amplification with Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10 further improves the performance over no amplification (Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1).

In FigureÂ D.3, we further investigate the impact of different amplification factors Î·ğœ‚\eta, while fixing Î³=10âˆ’5ğ›¾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5} for FashionMNIST and Î³=5Ã—10âˆ’6ğ›¾5superscript106\gamma=5\times 10^{-6} for CIFAR-10 as in the case of Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10 in FigureÂ D.2. We observe that the cases with Î·=5ğœ‚5\eta=5, Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10, and Î·=15ğœ‚15\eta=15 have similar performance, especially when getting closer to convergence. The performance gets worse when Î·ğœ‚\eta is too small (e.g., Î·=2ğœ‚2\eta=2), because the advantage of amplification is not fully attained in this case. When Î·ğœ‚\eta is too large (e.g., Î·=20ğœ‚20\eta=20), we observe higher fluctuation in the loss and accuracy values, which also leads to lower performance. For both datasets and their corresponding models considered in our experiments, we observe that the cases of Î·=5ğœ‚5\eta=5, Î·=10ğœ‚10\eta=10, and Î·=15ğœ‚15\eta=15 all give reasonably good performance. This suggests that a coarse choice of Î·ğœ‚\eta based on experience can be sufficient in practice, without the need of fine-grained tuning.
